reviews.text: I have stayed at this hotel a number of times over the past 20 years, and it is one of my favorite resort hotels. Unfortunately, the hotel has been bashed around the net lately, a lot of it not being true.
reviews.title: Interesting, historic, charming adobe

likes.disliked: — Cracked paint, problematic bathroom hardware, small parking lot

reviews.text: 1.Hotel has a serious car parking problem. The hotel building has a small parking lot in the back, which was almost always full. This is sad, but there are buildings around the hotel, and there is just no room to enlarge that lot. You get what you get, and that’s it. There is street parking overnight, and I did not see that being used too much, so there is some leverage there.
reviews.title: A nice hotel for those on a budget.

reviews.text: 2.I have seen comments that the desk stuff does not speak English well. I stayed at the hotel in July ’06 again, and found the desk staff to be fluent in English. On the other hand, it is true that short of the desk stuff there is nobody around. Essentially one carries one’s own luggage, but they do have an elevator (no luggage cart though).
reviews.title: A very big disappointment in June of 2004
The Post
reviews.text: 3.The hotel is redoing the kitchen, so the restaurant is closed. They are serving an excellent breakfast buffet, and they have a light café behind the desk which is open. They do not serve regular dinner/lunch, short of some drinks, and some snacks maybe in the café. Hopefully, once they get their kitchen up to speed, they can reopen the excellent restaurant. Ludwig Strasse, the street that the hotel is on, has changed considerably over the past 5 years. It has become a pedestrians only street, by the hotel, and a number of restaurants have opened on it lately, so lunch/dinner should not be a problem.

reviews.title: not what i hoped for.
reviews.text: 4.The hotel is wonderful, as far as being compared to a resort hotel, not to a big city center hotel. It has no garage, pool, gym, business center, etc. It is an old building, with antiques and charm. The paint is cracked in many places, and that is something that needs to be addressed ……. but it is not peeling off the walls. The bathroom hardware has various problems, but it is functional (will need to be replaced eventually once they get their kitchen under control).

reviews.title: Very disappointing experience in May 2004
reviews.text: After researching hotels in Garmisch-Partenkirchen in numerous guidebooks and consulting several websites (including this one), I decided several months in advance to make a reservation at the Posthotel Partenkirchen, based on several factors. First, it was widely reviewed as being an excellent hotel, although I have since noticed that some of the favorable reviews are quite dated. Second, its restaurant and bar were very well reviewed in several guidebooks and websites, and I was looking forward to trying some of its Bavarian specialties and hearing some live music there. Third, it supposedly offered room service, which I sometimes enjoy as a special treat when on vacation (ah, breakfast in bed). In addition, the location was good, it was historic and sounded like it had a lot of local character, the price for a single was reasonable, it took credit cards, and it offered hair dryers in the room.

reviews.title: posthotel perfection
reviews.text: When I arrived at the hotel in late afternoon/early evening, I was met by a sign on the front desk written in German and English, stating that the hotel's credit card machine was not working and that they required all guests to pay in cash. This was disappointing, and required some logistical maneuvering on my part since there is a limit on the amount of cash one can withdraw from an ATM per day, and my ATM card did not work in many of the machines I tried. The woman working the front desk when I checked in (who seemed to be the only hotel employee there at the time) did not speak English, and unfortunately I speak very little German other than a few basic phrases. She could, however, understand some English, and when I checked in I said hopefully that maybe by the time I checked out 3 days later the credit card machine would be working. "Nein, nein, nein," she replied as she shook her head emphatically. I thought this was curious. While she searched for my reservation and got the key for my room, I perused the "Guest Comment" book on the desk, which indicated that the credit card machine had not been working for quite some time, to the disappointment of quite a few guests.

reviews.title: Wonderful
reviews.text: I was given the key to room 50, which was on the 4th floor. Unfortunately the elevator was not working. So I struggled up several long flights of stairs with my bags. There was no one to assist with baggage. In fact, the hotel was so dark and quiet the whole time I was there that it was eerie. I never saw more than 2 employees in the entire hotel.

reviews.title: A favorite of mine
reviews.text: My room was a very small single, completely panelled in an attractive, rustic wood. The room was basically fine other than having somewhat dirty, worn-out blue carpeting which was fraying and had holes in places. The room looked out over a small overgrown garden which I'm sure was lovely at one time, but was now simply unkempt. The bathroom was in need of updating, an unattractive pink, but worked just fine. The room had a minibar which had a list of the many contents it was supposed to contain and the cost of each, but in actuality the minibar contained virtually nothing -- a bottle of water and a couple of sodas, nothing else.

reviews.title: Much Better than we hoped
reviews.text: While I was somewhat disappointed in the room, I was so exhausted after my lengthy journey with virtually no sleep that the thought of dragging my luggage back down all those stairs and trying to explain to the woman who didn't speak English that I was going elsewhere and then wandering around in the rain looking for somewhere else to stay did not appeal. All I really wanted was a bed. So I decided to stick it out.
